pull.title: Avoid unnecessary translations
pull.body: Working on translation, I found these translations introduced in #79, that are unnecessary (assuming the universal nature of the "BTC" string).

repo.name: gui
repo.description: Bitcoin Core GUI staging repository. Please do not fork unless for development reasons.

qt: Avoid unnecessary translations

events.body:
ACK 19d51a2907cc00244510460a658c482d1b4bdfda

Tested that these are all the occurrences in this file, and cross-checked for any occurrences in other files. We already set the `notr` attribute in other areas of the code such as [coincontroldialog.ui](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui/blob/master/src/qt/forms/coincontroldialog.ui#L215), [overviewpage.ui](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui/blob/master/src/qt/forms/overviewpage.ui#L142), and [sendcoinsdialog.ui](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui/blob/master/src/qt/forms/sendcoinsdialog.ui#L407).

Furthermore, `BTC` is treated as a symbol or unit of Bitcoin and is untranslatable by nature.
Is it really untranslated? What about languages that don't use the Latin alphabet at all?

> Is it really untranslated? What about languages that don't use the Latin alphabet at all?

For example? (not non-Latin languages, but abbreviated name "BTC" in non-Latin languages)

My three non-Latin languages use "BTC", btw.
I would expect Russian to use a Cyrillic abbreviation? Possibly Chinese and Japanese to get single-character units at some point?

> I would expect Russian to use a Cyrillic abbreviation? Possibly Chinese and Japanese to get single-character units at some point?

I've made a quick re-check of some multi-language online services. All of them use "BTC" in non-Latin languages.
